questions.text: True about PCOD:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Ratio of LH/FSH in PCOS is > 2:1(Option B,C and D ruled out)
  • Ratio of Fasting Glucose: Fasting insulin in PCOS < 4.5
  • FSH levels can be normal in PCOS, despite the presence of ovulatory dysfunction and hyperandrogenism. This is why relying solely on FSH levels is not sufficient for diagnosis.
  • The hormonal profile in Complete Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome (CAIS) may appear similar to that seen in PCOS with elevated LH, elevated testosterone, and normal FSH making differential diagnosis important in ambiguous genitalia or primary amenorrhea cases.

Lab Abnormalities

questions.text: Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in a 28-year-old obese woman presenting with Oligomenorrhea, infertility and hirsutism?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • A young woman presenting in the third decade with obesity, oligomenorrhea, infertility and hirsutism leaves no doubt for the diagnosis of PCOS.
    • Ovulatory dysfunction such as oligomenorrhea or hyperandrogenism.
    • Clinical or biochemical evidence of hyperandrogenism.
    • USG criteria
  • Since this female has oligomenorrhea and hirsutism, 2 of the criteria are being fulfilled.
  • Endometriosis presents with dysmenorrhea, chronic pelvic pain, dyspareunia, and infertility but is not typically associated with obesity or hirsutism, pelvic inflammatory disease usually follows infection with pelvic pain, fever, adnexal tenderness, and infertility due to tubal damage but without obesity or hirsutism, while Turner's syndrome presents with primary amenorrhea short stature, and streak ovaries, not with obesity, hirsutism, or secondary infertility(Option B,C and D ruled out).

questions.text: All are true about polycystic ovarian disease except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In patients of PCOS:

  • Alterations in gonadotropin releasing hormone pulsatility leads to preferential production of LH, as compared to FSH. Also estrogen has a positive feedback on LH and negative feedback on FSH which leads to increase in LH and decrease in FSH such that LH/FSH is > 2.1.(Option A and B ruled out)
  • Now the question arises whether this increase in LH is persistent. Most of the books do not state anything clearly except that there is an increase in the LH pulse amplitude and frequency.
  • In contrast to the characteristic picture of fluctuating hormone levels in the normal cycle, a 'steady state' of Gonadotropins and sex steroids can be depicted in association with persistent anovulation.
  • Approximately 70-80% of women with PCOS demonstrate frank elevations in circulating androgens particularly free testosterone, and 25-30% will have elevated levels of adrenal androgen metabolite, DHEAS(Option C ruled out)

questions.text: The first step in the management of hirsutism due to Stein-Leventhal syndrome is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Medical Treatment of Hirsutism

  • First-line for anovulation in PCOS: Lifestyle modification as in weight loss (as little as 5%) can restore ovulation and improve insulin sensitivity.Often more effective than pharmacologic treatment in obese or overweight patients.(Option B,C and D ruled out)

Drug therapy : If a patient has hirsutism the primary goal is lowering androgen levels to halt further conversion of vellus hairs to terminal ones.

Drugs used are :

  • OCPs -

Basis of using OCPs for hirsutism

  • The progestin component suppresses LH, resulting in decreased ovarian androgen production.
  • The estrogen component increases hepatic production of SHBG (sex hormone binding globulin), resulting in decreased free testosterone concentration.
  • Circulating androgen levels are reduced.
  • Estrogen decreases conversion of testosterone to Dihydrotestosterone in some by inhibition of 5-alpha reductase
  • OCPs are the first line of management of oligomenorrhea caused by PCOS. Progestins decrease total androgen level by reducing the activity of 5-alpha reductase. OCP usage results in an overall decrease in the formation of new androgen dependent hair growth and androgen-stimulated acne. All low dose OCP preparations are believed to have similar results. If therapy with OCPs is suboptimal , addition of an antiandrogen , such as spironolactone or finasteride, is recommended.

choices.text: May be associated with abnormal glucose

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding polycystic ovarian disease?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • PCOD is associated with anovulation and infertility, not post-dated pregnancy.
  • In PCOD, LH is typically elevated with a high LH:FSH ratio, it can cause infertility due to chronic anovulation, and it is often associated with insulin resistance leading to abnormal glucose metabolism.(Option A,B and C ruled out)
  • Associated with glucose intolerance (due to insulin resistance).
  • Can cause infertility.
  • Postdated pregnancy is not a complication of PCOD/PCOS.

choices.text: LH increased, FSH normal to low

questions.text: A 19-year-old girl presents with irregular menstrual cycles and increasing facial hair over the past 2 years. She has normal breast development (Tanner stage V) but sparse axillary and pubic hair. She denies sexual activity. On examination, her BMI is 28 kg/m2 and she has mild acne. A pelvic ultrasound reveals bilaterally enlarged ovaries with multiple peripherally arranged follicles and a normal-sized uterus:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In the given clinical scenario the clinical picture is classic for Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS):
    • Irregular cycles (oligomenorrhea/amenorrhea
    • Hirsutism and acne (due to hyperandrogenism)
    • Obesity (BMI 28)
  • Ultrasound findings:
    • Bilaterally enlarged ovaries with peripheral follicular arrangement (string of pearls appearance)
    • Normal breast development = Normal estrogen levels
    • Sparse axillary/pubic hair
  • In PCOS cases
    • ↑ LH causes excess androgen production from theca cells(Option A ruled out)
    • ↓ FSH impairs follicular maturation → chronic anovulation(Option C ruled out)
  • PCOS/PCOD is a syndrome manifested by amenorrhea hirsutism, obesity and enlarged ovaries.
  • Hormonal changes in PCOS:

questions.text: The following hormone is raised in polycystic ovarian syndrome:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In Polycystic Ovarian Syndrome (PCOS), there is a characteristic hormonal imbalance, including:
    • ↑ Luteinizing hormone (LH)
    • Normal or ↓ Follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH)
  • This elevated LH stimulates the theca cells of the ovary to produce androgens (like testosterone), contributing to:
    • Hirsutism
    • Anovulation
    • Acne
  • PCOS/PCOD is a syndrome manifested by amenorrhea hirsutism, obesity and enlarged ovaries.
  • 17-OH progesterone is elevated in congenital adrenal hyperplasia but not in PCOS, FSH is usually normal or low in PCOS, and TSH may be raised in hypothyroidism causing menstrual irregularities but is not a feature of PCOS.(Option A,B and D ruled out)

Diagnostic Criteria


Insulin Sensitizers

questions.text: A 28-year-old lady, Rani, is suspected to have polycystic ovarian disease. Sample for testing LH & FSH are best taken on the following days of menstrual cycle:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In PCOS the determination of the follicle stimulating hormone (FSH) and luteinizing hormone (LH) levels may help to confirm the diagnosis of polycystic ovaries. These are assayed on the second or third day of the cycle.(Option B,C and D ruled out)

questions.text: Most common cause of hirsutism in a teenage girl:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • PCOD is the most common cause of hirsutism.
  • PCOS most commonly affects teenage girls (15-25 years). Therefore, In teenage girls the most common cause of hirsutism is PCOD.

Diagnostic Criteria


Explanation of other options:

  • Pheochromocytoma(Option B): It is a rare tumor of adrenal medulla → secretes catecholamines (not androgens).Causes hypertension, palpitations, anxiety, but not hirsutism.
  • Obesity (Option C): Obesity exacerbates PCOS by increasing insulin resistance and peripheral androgen conversion.But not a primary cause of hirsutism.It is a contributing factor, not the main etiology.
  • Adrenogenital syndrome (Option D): It refers to Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia (CAH), especially 21-hydroxylase deficiency.Can cause hirsutism, ambiguous genitalia, salt-wasting crisis.But it's rare compared to PCOS.

questions.text: PCOD all of the following is seen except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Polycystic Ovarian Disease (PCOD), also called Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS), is a hormonal disorder characterized by hyperandrogenism, menstrual irregularity, and polycystic ovaries.
  • In PCOD, there is typically:
    • ↑ LH
    • Normal or ↓ FSH
    • Hence, LH:FSH ratio is often >2:1 or 3:1
    • FSH is not elevated

Explanation of other options:

  • Hirsutism (Option A): Due to increased androgen levels (testosterone, DHEAS)Leads to hirsutism, acne, and sometimes male-pattern baldness
  • Secondary amenorrhea (Option B): Women may experience Oligomenorrhea (irregular infrequent cycles),Secondary amenorrhea (absence of menstruation for >3 months after previous normal cycles)
  • Oestrogen(Option C): Women with PCOD typically have:
    • Unopposed estrogen (due to chronic anovulation)
    • This can lead to endometrial hyperplasia and increase risk of endometrial cancer
    • Serum estradiol levels may appear normal or mildly elevated but without the cyclical progesterone surge
  • Patients with PCOS, E1, levels are increased, E2 is at a follicular phase level.
  • Therefore, in PCOS = E1 > E2, i.e. Reversal of E2 : E1 ratio.
  • Elevated androstenedione levels contribute to an increase in estrone levels through peripheral conversion.

questions.text: Treatment of Hirsutism in PCOS, drugs used are:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Medical Treatment of Hirsutism

Drug therapy : If a patient has hirsutism the primary goal is lowering androgen levels to halt further conversion of vellus hairs to terminal ones.

Mechanical methods:

questions.text: True about Stein-Leventhal syndrome are all except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • BRCA - 1 is not associated with PCOS.
  • BRCA - 1 gene has been located at the chromosomal locus 17q21; women who inherit a mutated allele of this gene from either parent have an approx. 60-80% lifetime chance of developing Breast Ca and about 33% chance of developing Ovarian Ca.
  • Men who carry a mutant allele of the gene of BRCA-1 have an increased incidence of Prostate Ca, but not usually of Breast Ca.
  • BRCA - 2 gene which has been located to chromosome 11, is associated with an increased incidence of Breast Ca in both men and women.

Explanation of other options:

  • Oligomenorrhea and amenorrhea(Option (A)):
    • Menstrual irregularities are hallmarks of PCOS, including:
    • Oligomenorrhea (cycles >35 days)
    • Amenorrhea (absence of menstruation)
    • Due to chronic anovulation.
  • Theca cell hypertrophy(Option (B):In PCOS:
    • Theca cells in the ovary are hyperplastic and hypertrophied
    • They produce excess androgens under LH stimulation
    • This is a key feature in pathogenesis.
  • Innumerate cysts in ovary Classic "string of pearls" appearance on ultrasound(Option C ):
    • Multiple (≥12) peripheral follicles
    • Enlarged ovaries
    • These are arrested follicles, not true cysts.

Sonographic findings in case of PCOS include :

  • > 12 small cysts (2 to 9 mm in diameter)
  • Increased ovarian volume (> 10 ml).
  • Increased amount of stroma relative to the number of follicles.
    • Only one ovary with these findings is sufficient to define PCOS.
    • Other findings like Pearl necklace appearance in which follicles are distributed underneath the capsule in a row and perceived increase in stromal echogenicity have been eliminated as diagnostic criteria.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman presents with complaints of excessive facial hair growth and irregular menstrual cycles for the past 2 years. She has also noticed recent weight gain and acne. On examination, she has a BMI of 29 kg/m2 and mild hirsutism (Ferriman-Gallwey score: 10). Pelvic ultrasound reveals enlarged ovaries with peripheral follicular arrangement. Serum testosterone is mildly elevated; LH:FSH ratio is 3:1. She is not planning pregnancy at the moment.Which of the following is the most appropriate first-line pharmacological treatment for her condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This 23-year-old woman has clinical and biochemical features of Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS):
    • Hirsutism (Ferriman-Gallwey score ≥8),
    • Irregular menstrual cycles (>35 days),
    • Acne,
    • Mildly elevated testosterone,
    • LH:FSH ratio >2:1,
    • Ultrasound with "string of pearls" (peripheral follicular arrangement).
  • She does not desire pregnancy, so the first-line pharmacological management is a combined oral contraceptive pill (COCP) to:
    • Regularize menstrual cycles,
    • Reduce androgen levels (thus treating hirsutism and acne),
    • Offer contraception.
  • OCPs decrease adrenal and ovarian androgen production and reduce hair growth in nearly two thirds of hirsute patients. When an OCP is used to treat hirsutism, a balance must be maintained between the decrease in free testosterone levels and the intrinsic androgenicity of the progestin.

Progesterones with:

  • Thus, newer progestins with minimal androgenic activity are preferred for management of hirsutism in a patient of PCOD/PCOS.(Option A and C ruled out)

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl presents with a 3-month history of rapidly progressive facial hair growth, deepening of voice, and amenorrhea. On examination, she has coarse facial hair, clitoromegaly, and acne. There is no history of medication use or family history of hirsutism. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial investigation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This case presents features of rapid-onset virilization, which strongly suggests an androgen-secreting tumor rather than common causes like PCOS or idiopathic hirsutism.
  • Features include:
    • Rapid progression (3 months)
    • Virilizing signs: deep voice, clitoromegaly
    • Amenorrhea
    • No familial or medication cause
  • Symptoms may include deepening of voice, frontal balding, severe acne or hirsutism or both, increased muscle mass and clitoromegaly. Accordingly, serum testosterone levels may be used to exclude these tumors.
  • Accordingly, serum testosterone levels may be used to exclude these tumors. Although free testosterone is more sensitive, total testosterone remains the best approach due to lack of standardization of free testosterone assays. Total testosterone levels >200 ng/dL warrant evaluation for an ovarian lesion."

questions.text: Persistent anovulation not treated leads to all except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Persistent anovulation can lead to hirsutism due to androgen excess, endometrial carcinoma from unopposed estrogen, and an increased risk of cardiovascular disease due to associated metabolic syndrome.(Option A,C and D ruled out)
  • As far as ovarian cancer is concerned : Till date we believed in the theory of incessant ovulation for development of ovarian cancer which says the more a female ovulates, more are the chances of ovarian cancer.
  • So in patients of PCOS because of anovulation, incidence of ovarian cancer is not increased but because in patients of PCOS, clomiphene is used for ovulation induction therefore ovarian cancer can be seen.

questions.text: A 25-year-old comes with a chief complaint of hair growth all over body. She reports that her menses began at the age of 13 years and has always been very irregular. She also complains of acne. On physical examination there is hair around the nipples, chin and upper lip. There is no galactorrhea, thyromegaly, or temporal balding on examination. Pelvic examination is normal, and there is no evidence of clitoromegaly. All of the following should be included in the differential diagnosis based on the patient's history and physical examination, except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In the question-female is having hair growth all over the body, i.e. hirsutism.
  • This could be:
    • (1) Idiopathic hirsutism
    • (2) Congenital adrenal hyperplasia of late onset
  • Since she has irregular menses also:2 criteria of PCOS are also being fulfilled-so it can be a case of PCOS
  • This cannot be Sertoli leydig cell Tumor as there are no signs of virilization (e.g. clitoromegaly), there is only hirsutism.
  • Idiopathic hirsutism is possible since the patient has a normal exam and no virilization, Stein-Leventhal syndrome (PCOS) is very likely due to irregular menses, hirsutism, and acne, and late-onset congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) is also possible as it can present in adulthood with irregular menses and hirsutism. (Option A,B and C ruled out)

questions.text: Most common cause of hirsutism:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Hirsutism is defined as excessive growth of androgen dependant sexual hair or male distribution of hair in a female.
  • The most common cause of hirsutism is Polycystic Ovarian Syndrome.(Option B,C and D ruled out)
  • Polycystic ovarian syndrome accounts for 70 - 80% of cases of hirsutism, with idiopathic hirsutism being the second most frequent cause

choices.text: Marked elevation of LH in contrast to FSH
Elevation in the level of sex hormone binding globulin (SHBG) level

questions.text: The biochemical changes in established cases of Stein-Leventhal syndrome are as mentioned except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In PCOS (stein leventhal syndrome) the levels of SHBG decrease.
  • Marked elevation of LH in contrast to FSH with an increased LH:FSH ratio, insulin resistance contributing to hyperandrogenism, and elevated plasma testosterone levels are all true features of PCOS.(Option A,B and C ruled out)

questions.text: According to Ferriman Gallwey scoring system-hirsutism is diagnosed when score is more than:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Ferriman-Gallwey scoring is a scoring method for detecting hirsutism. In the original system hair growth at 11 sites was noted-
    1. Upper lip
    2. Chin
    3. Chest
    4. Upper back
    5. Lower back
    6. Upper abdomen
    7. Lower abdomen
    8. Upper arms
    9. Forearms
    10. Thighs
    11. Legs
  • In the modified method 2 sites were deleted-forearms and legs. Thus in the modified scoring system-hair growth is seen at 9 sites. In each of the nine locations-a score between 0-4 is given depending on growth of terminal hair Maximum score= 36.(Option B,C and D ruled out)
  • In caucasian women a score of 8 or higher is regarded as indicative of androgen excess.

questions.text: BMI of an overweight female is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • BMI of an overweight female is 25-29(Option A,C and D ruled out)

choices.text: Hyperinsulinemia is observed in about 40% to 80% of women with PCOS
Metformin has many other health benefits

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding hyperinsulinemia in women with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) is/are true?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Insulin resistance and compensatory hyperinsulinemia is observed in about 40% of women with normal weight and 80% obese women with PCOS. (Option A ruled out)
  • Hyperinsulinemia results in decreased hepatic synthesis of SHBG and increased ovarian androgen biosynthesis.(Option B ruled out)Metformin reduces weight, BMI fasting insulin levels, blood pressure and LDL cholesterol.
  • Metformin does not cause hypoglycemia neither in normoglycaemic patients nor with diabetic individuals.(Option C Ruled out)
